Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about experimental processes.
Ever wonder how a cholesterol would dance?
I learned about cell biology
Not really sure if I truly learned anything because there was too much information to remember
Overly advanced cell biology research techniques with no outlet for practical use as it is an introductory cell bio course.
I learned about the cell membrane and other cellular processes as well as experimental procedures commonly used in cell biology.
Didn't learn generally about cell biology but mostly just Cell membranes and exocytotic pathways.
Learned about cell biology and how researchers have shown multiple functions of the cell to be true.

I gained a better knowledge of how to think scientifically; I became far better at designing experiments and analyzing the experiments of others to find errors or explanations for observed phenomena. I also gained a far better knowledge of cell processes, particularly those relating to organelles usually neglected in my past bio courses, like the ER, the golgi, and the plasma membrane.
I learned way more about actin and myosin than I ever thought I would have to know.
I learned about multiple pathways of a cell.
Basics of Cell biology and Lab techniques. Practice in interpreting data and experimental procedures. Engaging with scientific literature.
I learned about what the field of cell biology is, some experimental methods that cell biologists use, and some specific pathways and characteristics of cells.
reading scientific papers, analyzing experimental methods, applying learning to situations in labs or in patients
I gained lots of knowledge about cell biology, with a heavy focus on cell membranes and experimental techniques used.

I learned how to think critically about cellular biological structures and processes in a very holistic way; I learned how to think in terms of experimental design and controls, analyzed hypotheses and propose alternatives.
How to teach myself when my professor couldn't do it himself
I learned about cell biology in a very different way, as the class was mainly applying our knowledge to different scenarios.
I learned how to really apply knowledge to situational questions and really think about the different ways to answer questions given all the knowledge I've gained.

Definitely gained so much more insight than I expected, 4000 characters cannot capture all that I've learned in Mark Mooseker's class. Broadly, I learned a lot about biological processes, but more importantly, I learned about HOW we discovered these processes. Gained a lot of exposure to complex experimental methods and what happens in the event that these methods are preformed improperly.
Thinking scientifically, biologically, applying experiments to practical situations

How to read and discuss a scientific paper, how to interpret data, how to make predictions, how to design experiments, how to be a real scientisthow not to be overwhelmed by 100++ slide lectures. Oh, and a lot about actin.
I learned how to think through biological concepts and be able to interpret novel data.
This course is unlike any other I have taken, but perhaps in a good way. the material is dense but the instructor/TAs help to break it down.

I gained extensive knowledge of specific pathways within the cell in addition to increased competency in scientific thought. I also gained a functional fluency in science vocabulary to the point where I can read and understand scientific papers.
i learned a lot more about cell bio
I learned a lot of basic cell biology principles and experimental techniques.
Even though this was a very difficult course, I learned about the pathways, individual actors, and ways to approach experimental styles and procedures.
I learned a lot about the details behind the processes that I learned in AP Biology in high school.

I learned about the basics of cell membrane physiology, protein synthesis, endocytosis, and the cytoskeleton. This course provides a solid foundation for further study in topics relating to cell biology.

BIOL 102 dove deep into cell biology. I was naive to anticipate a typical high school biology-like class. Instead, we learned advanced lab techniques and read primary literature related to cell biology. We gained insight into how structures of cells were discovered and how cellular processes were proven.
I learned a TON about how to analyze scientific papers, how to design experiments, and the many discoveries within Cell Biology.
Intense details of cellular structures, functions, mechanisms, and some compounds
The mitochondria is the powerhouse of the cell. On a more serious note, I gained the knowledge of the inner workings of cells.
I gained one very important skill  the ability to study from lecture slides that were not organized in a way to foster learning. It should serve me well in the next three years

Through failure of higher degree than I had ever experienced before, I truly believed I learned a different type of resilience. I struggled to adapt to the different teaching style and scope of content that was well beyond my abilities. I was discouraged because I had always thought that biology was a fascinating and enjoyable subject. I found the challenge and my lack of success to be daunting and discouraging; however, with the help of Professor Lin and peer tutors, I eventually found a way to understand the material presented. This gave me a much more positive final view of the course and topic. I appreciate the challenge that the course provided. My gpa may not end up appreciating it, but I think that it was worthwhile to prepare me for future science courses.
I learned how to read/skim/ understand scientific papers.
It gave me a lot of insight on the experimental evidence behind what we were learning.
I learned a lot about techniques and experiments that led to a lot of the knowledge that is know in regards to cell biology. The course is definitely focused on these aspects.
This course not only taught me the basics of cell biology way beyond what I learned in high school biology courses but also introduced me to essential tools/methods used in actual cell biology labs.
I definitely learned how to teach myself

I gained so much knowledge in this class, it's actually kind of insane. I learned not only material, but I learned how to think about biology in a way that I had never had to before. I learned large, overlapping themes that I hope will help me in future science courses.
I learned how to apply what I learned in a lab setting.
I definitely learned a lot of biology and biological techniques. Even though the course wasn't always pleasant, it was informative and I appreciated it.
I learned a lot about the functions within a cell.  I also learned a whole new "language" as most of the vocabulary used was new to me.
I learned about the biological processes that govern the cell, and how to apply these processes to answer complex problems.
I learnt a lot about research methods and applying knowledge to lab situations.

Theoretically, how to prepare specimen for analysis under the microscope, use primary and secondary antibodies, determine the necessity and sufficiency of cell components whose function is a foundation in cell biology, etc. How to problem solve in the lab.
Different processes that occur in our body on the cellular level; patience and confidence in myself
Fundamentals of cell biology, research paper reading and experimental analysis skills.
I learned how to apply what I learned in class in many different settings. Other than that, I do not feel like I benefitted from this course at all.
Cell membrane physiology, vesicular transport, lab methods, how to read research papers
This course gave an in depth exploration of the manner in which cells function.
I learned more about the cell and about biology.

The question style on the midterm and final were different from other teaching styles I experienced in other classes. I had to learn how to evaluate all of the variables present and narrow down the specific one that could make a difference in a chosen system that the question was focusing on. It really changed my perspective on how to approach problems and find solutions.
Application of biology information instead of just regurgitating facts.
I learned to download lecture slides and take notes on them. Also, to study a week well in advance of any exam.
I learned about myosin, actin, membranes, the endoplasmic reticulum, the Golgi, and other things in cell biology. Also had to learn to read, discuss and analyze scientific research papers.
I learned a lot about cell biology. I didnt know how big of a realm before.
Various cell functions including endocytosis, actin and microtubules, co-translation of proteins, etc.
nothing at all.
I learned about different lab methods used in biology and some basic structures of the cell.
understanding of cell biology from plasma membrane (lipids and protein mobility) to RER and Golgi to cytoskeleton

If you engage with the material Mooseker covers in lecture beyond just listening to him in lecture, you will learn a lot about cell bio--particularly about membranes because he is really in to lipid bilayers. You'll also gain a much better understanding of the research techniques biologists use, which is probably the most valuable takeaway from this course especially if you are considering doing any type of research.
I developed the basic skills required to be involved in a research lab.
This course was great for developing critical thinking skills.
I learned how to study better and also how to connect ideas better, because the course does challenge you in being able to compile everything you know and have complex answers to complex problems.
Lab techniques, reading scientific papers

Knowledge: biochemical techniques, microscopic techniques, cellular processes, cell membrane, cell division
Skills: critical thinking, problem solving, coming up with experimental procedures, analyzing experimental results
Fundamental cell bio knowledge
I learned how to deal with lots of information and refined lab techniques
i learned
New scientific method.
Great information about the cell and its processes.
Basics of cell biology and experimental techniques
I learned about the cell in DETAIL: exocytosis, endocytosis, motor proteins, a lot about membranes, etc. It was a very meticulous course. I learned how to better study for detailed course material.

I really enjoyed this class because we covered a tremendous amount of material that was very interesting. I learned how to quickly read paragraphs of text and pull out only the relevant information. I learned how to really think out of the box when it came to biology, which I have never done before. I trained my mind to think like a scientist rather than memorizing machine.
I learned the fundamentals of Cell Biology and useful tool kits for scientific experiments.
How experiments are performed and evaluated

I learned the different mechanisms of the cell well. Psets helped me understand the processes. You can understand the processes as much as you want; but its the problem solving part which is the real bottle neck and will hold you back.
I learned so much bio, especially methods and techniques used in biology. In doing so, you have to understand the basic concepts before you master the techniques.
I gained knowledge about Cell Bio as well as many fundamental lab techniques, also how to actually read and dissect a scientific paper.
Very detailed, in-depth introduction to cell bio. Major topics included cell membrane physiology, endocytosis, secretory protein pathways, and the role of microtubules and actin in the cytoskeleton.
I developed a deep foundation for cell biology.
I learned several experimental methods and principles integral to cell biology. I also gained skills in reading scientific papers and interpreting results.
Knowledge of how our cells work
Biology evaluation and paper reading

We go through 3 "Tool Kits" which teach you about different laboratory techniques. We also learned about the cell membrane, the secretory system on a cellular level, actin and microtubules, and a bit about mitosis.
Collaborating
I developed my skills on cell biology and gained a more in depth and detailed understanding of what I had learned in previous biology classes.
Critical thinking. Reading though questions and having to decide what information is relevant. Reading and analyzing scientific literature.

I finally understood how to read and interpret scientific papers, including figures and datasets. I gained an understanding of several biological processes, pathways, and experimental techniques. I learned how to think more scientifically - this class was a completely new way of looking at biology, as it was less memorization based, and much more about applying what I knew to novel experimental situations. I did learn a lot, but that was largely due to the extensive labor of Samantha Lin during her enrichment session, and the peer tutors in their many office hours or review sessions.
I learned a lot about experimental methods and experiments having to do with cell biology
I learned about receptors and movement from the er to the golgi and the cytoskeleton.
I learned somewhat about a few topics in cell bio in lots of detail. I also learned about some cell bio techniques.

- A fairly good basic understanding of cell biology
- The ability to critically read scientific papers
I learned a lot of minutiae regarding cellular biology.
experimental method and how to read scientific papers
I was able to learn not only an introduction to cell biology, but further improve upon teamwork, time management, and utilizing resources such as the peer tutors and Professor Lin's hours.
I learned how to interpret data and graphs and use biological concepts to explain observations and results.
This course taught me about cell function and structure and the experiments used to determine those things and at the same time improved my scientific paper reading skills.
How biological techniques such as staining, fixation, and immunoprecipitation work.
This course really challenged by critical thinking skills and was rather difficult, especially having no bio experience prior to this class except for 101.

This class taught me an introduction into cellular processes and cell components. I also learned how to read scientific papers quite well, since we had to read and review them every week in discussion section. This came in handy in my internship.

I learned most of the fundamentals of cell biology -- membrane physiology, vesicular pathways, mitosis, etc. Everything you would expect, except with a weird emphasis on the cytoskeleton and membranes, and a noticeable absence of really important stuff. Like we never mentioned the mitochondria in the entire course?? I know that oxidative phosphorylation is super important from AP bio, but it never made an appearance in this course, weirdly.
i learned how to think critically
I learned about key concepts in cell biology, different experimental techniques, landmark papers and how to analyze data to draw conclusions.
Went into great detail about various bio topics like experimental methods, protein secretion, microscopy, endocytosis, and mitosis. Learned to read papers quickly and comprehensively.
I now know so much more about cell membranes than I ever thought I would. I have also developed my willingness to ask for help.
I learned a lot about the detailed inner workings of the cell and the research that went into understanding it.
How to study more effectively. More detailed analysis of functions and pathways involving cells
I learned how to apply information to new types of problems. A lot of creative thinking

During this course I gained a significantly deep insight into the workings of the cell, and into the underlying functions of various cellular activities. I acquired a firm understanding of various techniques that are used in the processing of tissue and cells, and also in carrying out various different experimental procedures when it comes to the biological sciences. The course aimed at both providing a theoretical and empirical background on cell biology, focusing both on the cell processes that happen and on the ways in which we can study and understand these processes.

This is a hard class. It would be improved by clearer explanations in lecture and slowing down a bit. 

It helps students to think in a different way
I learned nothing

Strengths: volume of peer tutors 
Weaknesses: lecturer doesn't know how to communicate complex topics to an intro-level student body

Strengths: Dr. Lin and the peer tutors. Weaknesses: There is way too much information. Dr. Mooseker goes through at least 100 slides per lecture. With that, it is hard to know what is truly expected of us.

Strengths: I guess you learn a lot?
Weaknesses: Professor Mooseker mumbles and speaks in biology. This can be hard to understand. A microphone amplifies the volume but does not clear up the mumbling. Also sometimes he would do demonstrations but I was concerned about his safety? And his health? I don't want him to fall off the table. Course needs a 4 minute break in the middle of the 75 minute lecture to stretch and take a break. Otherwise people start dozing off halfway through.
The pace of teaching could be slowed to facilitate a deeper understanding of concepts.

A strength of the course was that the material covered was interesting and engaging, but a weakness is that there were no practice exams, and having more practice problems would be useful for studying.
General organization of lectures and what to expect on the psets.  Importance of concepts was never clear.

The class moves way too quickly, and the instructor doesn't explain a whole lot during lecture. He introduces a concept, reads off the powerpoint (which frequently is just bulk chunks of text), and then expects you to apply that concept throughout the rest of the lecture, which leaves students lost and confused. I think simply a reduction of complicated vocabulary could go a long way. There's no need to use proper scientific jargon. This is an INTRO biology course. Please don't tell me that "glycosyl groups can play a key role in protein folding in ERe.g. via membrane bound lectin calnexin. Calnexinbinds to N-linked oligosacch. on unfolded proteins that retain a terminal glucose. It releases when the glucose is removed.  If the protein is not folded a glucosyltransferase replaces the sugar, and calnexin rebinds. The cycle continues until the protein is properly folded." Rather, say "a chaperone protein binds to the glucose on unfolded protein and tries to fold it. If it doesn't fold correctly, it is recognized by another enzyme that reattaches a glucose, and this goes on until the protein folds correctly."
Well structured, but a lot of material covered in very small amount of time. I wish the discussion sections were focused more on material covered in class, like going over what we had learned.

This is a fantastic course that forces students to think critically and examine where the science they know comes from; in its focus on experimental method, it is unlike any course I have taken before, and it was eye-opening. I have no genuine improvements to suggest; the class is extremely well structured.
The professor goes too fast through the content and often uses language that is difficult to understand.

The teaching scholars, TFs, and weekly review sessions were incredibly helpful for understanding the material.  The material itself was often confusing and we would often cover a lot of material, but not thoroughly.

I think sometimes Professor Mooseker gets caught up in the fact that he's studied cell bio for years and this is just an intro course. Sometimes it's enjoyable to see how much he knows, but other times it's hard to keep up with what's going on in the lecture. However, I think the course improved in this throughout the half semester by incorporating review sessions and having students ask more questions. I was definitely able to grasp the material eventually.
It was hard to follow in class because the prof moved on very fast. I wished that the teaching slides were more concise and condensed.

Great course if you truly like biology, really pushed the students to engage with biology at a new level. Definitely a not so gentle learning curve for many students and at first not intuitive but I don't think the nature of this can be changed greatly with out damaging the integrity of the course.

Strengths - interesting, learned a lot about what cell biology is as a field
Weaknesses - disorganized and way too fast, I think I would have learned a lot better if this class had been slowed down a lot and taught in a more organized manner
Strengths - Professor Lin, enrichment, review sessions; weaknesses - lectures were very very dull.

I liked the format of the course overall. Most of the problems required the complex application of concepts, which I found really helpful and conducive to learning. However, in most areas, the course material was too specific/specialized and seemed to assume that we had already gotten a thorough background in cell biology.

Strengths: well organized

Weaknesses: lectures were difficult, mostly assumed students understood the basics of cell biology

I thought  the class was well organized. There was a good split between learning material, learning experimental techniques, and reading scientific papers. I think the class was a good intro into scientific research in general.

The course was very interesting and I feel that I have learned a lot of valuable information. The major weakness of the course was that lectures moved unbelievably quickly and a lot of the fundamental details of certain experiments or concepts were not explained as much as they should have been the first time around.

I think that it is difficult to teach to so many students with varying backgrounds in STEM. As someone with limited exposure to the kind of thinking emphasized in this class, it was a real struggle and I often felt as if I would ultimately fail out of the class. The enrichment was probably the only reason I kept at it even though is class is a prerequisite for my major.

The teaching fellows/Samatha Lin and peer tutors were the only good part about this course. First of all, the curriculum was ridiculous given I now know the way lysosomal hydrolase is tagged but have no idea how to label a cell's organelles. Honestly, biology 102 was the worst class I have ever taken. Lectures were messy and not linear, while slides ranged from incomprehensible (with various spelling mistakes) to irrelevant. Material introduced felt very disconnected, and there was no unifying theme of the course. Mooseker may have discovered all but one myosin, but he certainly did not take a class in how to teach. The whistles are a nice idea, but any time the mean score for an exam is a C- I think there should be serious consideration about whether a teacher should be teaching. I think this professor had a knowledge of the material that was so beyond an introductory course that he had to way to explain concepts in a coherent way for first year students to understand. Had Samantha Lin or any teaching fellow taught the course, I genuinely think everyone would have done well. What's more, the midterm and final were entirely disconnected from the important ideas of the course, and instead was basically Mooseker asking us if we could solve problems in research that we've never conducted. I do not think that an introductory biology course should have such a research heavy focus, given that many of the students enrolled are taking the course for premedical requirements, not because they want to get involved in research. I know very little about cell biology (aside from the very specific mechanisms of how lysosomal proteins are tagged for the lysosome), and I'm very disappointed in this course. I think perhaps biology should be tracked like chemistry is, and there should be an introductory course for people who did not take AP bio in high school.
The class itself is very interesting. However, the professor goes too fast during lecture and the slides are very confusing.

Strengths- learned a lot, challenged consistently, great professor (Mooseker), great TAs and Peer Tutors, great lecture slides 
Weaknesses- rushed towards the end, very challenging (both a pro and a con)

Strengths- kindness of instructors, review sessions
Weaknesses- lectures can be extremely confusing

Professor Mooseeker is passionate about the material he teaches and does a lot to help students succeed in the course, between the whistles handed out at the first lecture to the annotated papers and outlines to the Sunday afternoon review sessions. The course itself has a lot of resources, between the course coordinator Professor Lin and the team of TFs and peer tutors. However, if you do not take advantage of these resources, you will not succeed. The course is hard, and its impossible to understand the material by merely going to lecture. The lectures are quite dense. If you put time in, you get a lot out about experimental design and thinking about science. However, the amount of time you have to put in is very different from Biol 102 to just go through the lectures and make sure you understand everything. The psets take a while but are worth putting time into  theyre interesting and similar to exam style.

There was not nearly enough support, or the support given was not the right type. Giving more practice questions and slowing down lectures would be the most effective help. Also, having more organized slides or review sheets.
Theres a great amount of stuff in a short amount of time and the format of the class is not great

The greatest strength of this course is the difficulty, which truly opened my eyes to the reality of a career in Biology. Luckily, as the course continues you'll get more and more acquainted with reading scientific papers, and analyzing them becomes a lot easier.
I liked the course. Sometimes, it seemed to be a little too focused on the details of a singular cellular process rather than a more broad introduction and overview for understanding.
i think that a lot of students really struggle in this class and i think that more peer tutors should be implemented.
The lectures weren't very good but discussion section was. I wish information was presented more clearly and a little slower in lecture.

Strengths: Very important information and enrichment was beyond helpful! Prof Mooseker is also an incredibly smart man so it was nice to learn from him. 

Weaknesses: The lecture was often at too fast of a pace, the lecture notes were a bit difficult to understand, and the PSETs sometimes went beyond the scope of what we had learned in class. The

The material was taught very quickly, and the powerpoint slides that Professor Mooseker uploaded lacked information to give the images context.  He often lectured faster than I was able to take notes, and much of what he said was not included in the slides.

The course's main strength is that it provided an introduction to the experimental design and analysis needed to answer questions about cells and cellular processes. This was a very engaging and intellectually stimulating approach to the subject. However, sometimes there was a degree of assumed knowledge (such as the names and locations of certain organelles) that some students did not have. I think that the instructors should either present these basic facts during lectures, or assign readings that present these facts to the students. Knowing relevant vocabulary going into lecture would enable students to better engage with the experiments and analyses of these experiments presented in the course.

Strengths: You learn how to apply scientific knowledge to data and experiments, and even learn how to develop a proper hypothesis, data, and methods

Weakness: This class went way too quickly for an introductory course. Considering that you have to implement whistles to the class in order to slow the pace of the lecture already shows that you should probably change the pace of the class in general. The class could be better structured, but I do believe with a lot of work put into the class you can do well.

Strengths: the lecture slides are posted online, which help with studying; piazza allowed us to have long questions answered and see answers to other students questions
Weaknesses: almost uncomfortable lecture pace

Strengths: Course Material was a bit tough to grapple with at times but overall was very engaging and enriching. Prof. Mooseker is a great man and provides excellent help if sought out; his expertise is unmatched.
Weaknesses: The homework and the manner in which it was graded was frustrating and did not seem to reflect the broader ideas of the course.

Taught too fast for a lot of people (tho conversely I enjoyed the speed because it helped me stay awake)! Slow down and be realistic from early on what can not be gotten into given the level of detail provided
It was quite interesting, but the sheer volume of info per lecture was enough to cause you to rethink your decision to take this class.

strength: it challenged me
weakness: the challenge was in ways that were disappointing. for example, questions were asked on a slide that were asked in class but not posted afterwards, making it cumbersome, if not impossible, to learn from the information
A ton of material and lectures were kind of confusing. Professor Lin is amazing.
I think the actual information taught is useful but the amount is just so much to learn.
The professor is pretty good at letting you know what will be on exams but sometimes you will learn something in great depth that you didnt have to.

Strengths: Professor Lin and the peer tutors have been crucial in helping me understand the fast-paced material.
Weakness: I never truly learned the material in lectures because the slides were presented too quickly and explained in terms I did not understand. Perhaps students can gain more in class if "pre-lecture" summaries or "pre-lecture overview" peer tutoring sessions were given. We are given pre-lecture slides to look over, so I guess this is really on the part of the student's initiative.
weakness: We didn't learn much about intro cell biology that you would expect to learn about in an intro bio course, and Professor mooseker is a terrible teacher.

I think that the only weakness of the course was the lectures were very, very dense. I understand the course is just material-dense so the lectures had to be full of information, but it was stressful in lecture when there were so many slides with so much information. It made test-taking stressful because there was so much potential information to be tested, and I felt that I had to know everything. Professor Mooseker and Professor Lin were the two of the strengths of the course. They are both so involved and wanted to see use grow as students. There were always demonstrations and in-class activities that made learning fun.

I hated how in-depth this class went. The whistle system, in theory, was great for detecting anonymity during lecture when people are not following along, except, in practice, whoever blows a whistle gets a mic shoved up their face and then they HAVE to ask a question. But how do you ask a question when you don't even know what to ask? And 'I don't understand anything you just said" sounds too stupid? I felt so inferior because of my classmates already coming in knowing about all of the content when I'm not even familiar with the terminology yet. For an intro bio course, this just assumed you had knowledge on the topic beforehand, and if you didn't, then you should read the textbook and understand all of the vocabularies within a day. I didn't like how it felt like I needed to attend Enrichment when the course is an INTRO course, but I guess I'll have to if I want to pass for the rest of the sequence.

One strength is that the peer tutors and support system around the class is good. Also, the problem sets helped a lot in helping me understand the material in class. A weakness is that the course starts at a rapid pace from the beginning, and Mooseker definitely is not the most engaging lecturer.

Strengths: This course covers a LOT of material and I feel like I learned so much. 
Weaknesses: This course was very in-depth and had so much material to cover.  I often felt that I was drinking information out of a fire hose.

The strengths of this class is that it goes very into depth of the cellular biological processes. However, the class is quite poorly organized, the problem sets are way too difficult and require an extremely well grasp of the concept, and the professor does not coherently explain the concepts. It could be improved by condensing the information on the slides to provide only the important information, providing more practice problems, and simplifying the questions on the problem sets as well as midterm and final.
The lectures were dense and went very fast.

Lecture notes arent well-organized; cant tell what the key points are even though there are lecture outlines  would be more helpful to know what to study for on exams had we had the key concepts structure like in BIOL101 with Koleske. Also, the first discussion paper on the rearward movement of cells was very foreign and difficult, given that there are some of us with little to no lab work background nor experience with academic scientific text  and yet we were expected to read them practically ourselves without any helpful annotations, and come into discussion section ready to discuss? The only papers that were really understandable were the ones where Mooseker actually went over in class, because they were actually relevant. The first paper was just strange. The difficulty of the PSETs and the inflexible grading scale is also frustrating because I still dont know what the balance of being wordy vs being thorough in my answer should be, since BIOL 101 was so focused on having sentence limits for our answers, but when I simplify my answer in a PSET question, I get points marked off for not using specific words/phrases describing a pathway. I dont know how were supposed to get any points on a PSET question without talking to someone who has been in a lab before and knows whats pratical and feasible when answering a question about lab. Again, this course assumes we know a lot of biological research for some reason, even though its literally an intro bio course. Id also like to point out that the students who know the answers to Moosekers questions in class are the exception/amount of students who have had the privilege/knowledge to find research opportunities and have had a headstart in thinking critically about biological research issues that the rest of the class does not.

Strengths -- an amazing course coordinator in Professor Samantha Lin who kept me sane through the whole course. A passionate and knowledgeable lecturer in Professor Mooseker.
Weaknesses -- WAY too much content covered for an introductory biology course in cell biology. For someone who did not have a strong background in biology coming into the class, it was insanely difficult to keep up with the course. Mooseker talks really fast and even with the whistles, we get through so much information in 75 minutes -- I can not retain it all.

The giant scope and complexity of subject matters covered in this course is both its biggest strength and mostly obvious weakness. 

The course never feels remotely like an actual introductory course, but to those already prepared in biological and chemical fundamentals it is an impressively rigorous foray into the fundamentals of cell biology.

I found myself constantly questioning the relavance of what we were learning; there seemed to be no progression or connection between the various topics. The professor was extremely weak in communicating the information in a clear way; although, he was definitely funny and laid back, which was nice to see. The only strength was Sam Lin who coordinated this. She was so committed to ensuring our success. The presentations were so difficult to follow; there was no organization as there were pre and post lecture slides, which were always different. As a result, I had trouble figuring out which information was salient and which information wasn't. The course turned me away from biology and I feel as though I learned way more in AP Biology.

Strengths: bio tutors and TAs were hugely helpful. The structure of discussion is very good for learning how to discuss research papers. 

Weakness: the speed and style of lecturing was impossible to keep up with. 100 slides per class? If the professor is getting out of breath from the pace he sets himself its probably time to re-evaluate

Strengths: Samantha Lin was in excellent instructor, and enrichment had an incredible impact on my performance and understanding of the course material

Weaknesses: The professor did not explain core concepts in an extremely clear manner and often used advanced terms not known to most students without clarification or descriptions.
The lectures kept going and was a little confusing.

The course was very challenging, to the point where it felt like we were supposed to know a lot more than what you would expect for an intro course. However, at the end of the day, the greater challenge proved to be a learning strength in the course that helps with upper level science, so it was helpful.
I was unsure what was expected from me for the first midterm.

Strengths:

The challenging nature of Bio 102 allowed students to work together to succeed on assignments.

Weaknesses:

Why aren't homework assignments posted a week in advance of their due date? Why does off-sequence 102 seem so much harder than on-sequence 102? Why doesn't he write an answer key for homeworks? Why do the TAs grade assignments so harshly? Why is the Bio sequence split up into half-semester modules? So many questions.

It is a good overview of the information but there was way too much information presented to us in a very short amount of time. Information that was barely a bullet point on one of ~60 slides, and not talked about that much in lecture, was apparently important. The information was just not interesting and the "big picture" was not talked about enough. For me, in order to understand really small cellular processes, I also have to know why this process is happening and what this means on the organismal level, and this course very rarely went over it.
It was hard to understand techniques, having never been in a lab before. If someone doesnt have the goal of research?m, its hard to engage with the class.

Strength: great support system outside of the class
weakness: professor was not the best at teaching
Way too much content for half semester courses
no strengths. weaknesses: impossible to pay attention in lecture. ended up learning everything on my own through going through the slides. material is also not that interesting.
Went way too quickly and we learned too many specific things rather than focusing on the greater concept and its importance.

This course could be improved if the instructor spoke much more slowly and covered more basic biology concepts, as this course was titled Introduction to Cell Biology. The course covered much more advanced topics than expected and at a very rapid speed. There were not many resources for students who did not have a strong background in biology, and it was difficult to determine what I needed to study in order to catch up.

Strengths: helpful instructors, psets and exams tested application not memorization; Weaknesses: too much material was taught in one semester, so that the final exam focused more on recalling what we learned from a mental table of contents to figure out which material would apply to which question

Strength is it was very challenging and pushed us to our limits. Professor Lin really helped us reach this limit. Weakness is it was very fast-paced and did not leave much room for us to breathe despite its difficulty.
The course moves ridiculously fast. Students would certainly learn and retain more if the course didn't go through 90+ lecture slides every lecture.
The course covered cell biology extremely in depth, and it didnt feel like an introductory course. I do think the slides could have been better organized.
This course should be co-taught by Alon Miller and Sam Lin. What is Mooseker doing.

The course material is very interesting and I felt accomplished after the course. However, lectures move very quickly and I think that the course gives off an air of being inquiry-based, but in reality the answers are in the slides. There are also many students who are not especially prepared for the course and the material may be above their heads and isnt a good introduction to cell bio. That said, the course is interesting and engaged my curiosity a lot.
Weaknesses: not very organized/structured lectures, very hard to follow
Lectures are crammed and not taught well. Homework assignments are not fair given the content taught in lecture.

Strengths: learn a lot of info, learn problem solving skills, discussion sections were engaging and helpful
Weaknesses: lectures were difficult to follow
Great instructors. Content during lecture was very dense, though.

Strengths: discussion is helpful and professors care 

Weakness: material poorly taught, lots of stuff doesnt make that much sense

the most useful recourses were the lecture slides. the problem is that the teacher went through them too quickly for them to be comprehensible and therefore i learned next to nothing in lecture and had to review everything on my own later in order to properly learn it for the first time. also the papers we read weren't that helpful because most of the TAs were pretty bad and didn't do a good job of explaining them. it could be improved if the teacher actually used the slides to structure the course and not just talk with slides zooming by in the background. it would also be better if the TA sessions werent just about papers but were also for asking general questions about the material, and having better TAs is needed.
A lot of information covered. Some information assumed from prior knowledge. A very dense class.
Lectures were too long and too much content
Lectures are not enough to fully understand the material.

In this class students regularly do poorly on exams and midterms, then get curved up. I think this is a fundamental flaw - if students do poorly year after year, and this is not changing, then the teaching should be adjusted rather than the grading scheme. The lectures of this class are almost pointless to go to, and when I went to review sessions it was if I was learning the material for the first time. The format of the tests reads like this is a lab course, with situations being given rather than questions asked about comprehension. I think that being able to apply knowledge given is an important skill, but it requires a level of comprehension beyond what should be expected.

The course is very practical in the understanding it provides students of not only the fundamental processes that drive cellular and sub cellular biological mechanisms but also the lab techniques necessary to observe, assess and elucidate these mechanisms. I find myself leaving the course with a far more applicable knowledge of biological practice than Ive ever had from a bio class before. The drawbacks mostly reside in the presentation of the course material. The lectures move quickly and often with little additional explanation beyond what is given on the slides. Parsing through the meaningful and unneeded information presented in lecture was always a difficulty.

It forces you to learn a lot, seek out help, and develop strategies to do better. Some weaknesses are that extra help is offered to a select-few people. It needs to be emphasized how important extra help can be and be more accessible.

A strength was that most of the information taught is important to know if you are going into a science field. A weakness was that too much material was covered in such a short amount of time, so it was very difficult to wrap my mind around it. Also, some of the material was not explained or presented in a way where it made sense.
Professor Mooseker was always there for his students but I do think that he could be more organized with lectures. The whistles helped at some point but then the fire ran out.
More peer tutors in the beginning
Needs more emphasis on problem solving. Knowing the content doesn't matter unless you know how to apply them.

Ok. The slides are not clear for a lot of the time. Like they just dont make sense and everything could be put into easier words. Please please include like a summary sheet of each lecture or unit because I spent so much time trying to figure out what things meant from the slides.

I thought reading scientific papers relating to the material was really useful in developing my understanding of science as well as the material itself. There was just a lot of information though and it was poorly organized and explained in lecture.

Strengths: All topics covered were studied in-depth. Diagrams and photos included in the PowerPoint presentations were very helpful in explaining concepts taught in class. P-sets were challenging but not impossible based on what was taught in class, and they were a very good reflection of exam questions. 

Weaknesses: Way too challenging (in my opinion) for an intro-level course. Concepts could have been taught and understood better if the class did not move at such a ridiculously fast pace and if the proper time was taken to explain concepts.
Weakness: The professor does not know how to explain biology to confused students that are not as experienced as he is in biology .

The course had very specific material that I felt was more geared towards a cell biology course and not an intro course. The lectures were sometimes hard to follow. That being said, I felt that the content was very interesting.

Strengths- Interesting course material that is not usually taught to an intro bio class, thought-provoking, engaging, Professor Mooseker was very accessible

Weaknesses- It was sometimes unclear what PSET questions were asking, Sometimes there was an overwhelming amount of material that was taught too quickly for students to understand
I didnt understand what was happening in lecture. Moving slower or defining more terms that we might not be familiar with would be helpful.
Weaknesses: taking tests

I thought that Mooseker's teaching style was a bit disorganized, as he does not follow the same 1 lecture=1 set of slides per day like Prof Koleske did in 101. Mooseker also wasn't very good at explaining difficult topics, because the content is so usual and sensical for him since he's been working in the field his whole life. There were times when the entire class was very confused. I think this could be improved by going slower and really following through on stating all the details. Also repeating things a few times rather than just moving on would help as well. It is difficult to absorb anything in the class while you sit there because it goes so fast.

Strengths: Prof Lin
Weakness: Prof Mooseker moves through content extremely fast

I think that the material was very parficular and even through memory it was difficult to understand the questions asked. Very difficult course. He may just be too intelligent to reach us... because he is so knowledgeable and knowing in the field he is almost too qualified to teach an intro course.
Dr. Mooseker was not a very good lecturer. I learned more during the TA review sessions than his lectures.

The lectures were hard to follow and very fast. The homeworks took very long and grading seemed very inconsistent from TA to TA. However the review sessions that were offered were very helpful. I gained overall a ton of knowledge.
Lectures were difficult to understand, and sort of disorganized. The review sessions helped.

I definitely believe that the course attempted to cram too much content into a very condensed period of time. I believe that several of the topics discussed in lecture were covered too quickly for students to understand. Additionally, separating the course into modules and toolkits was helpful to an extent, however I did not like how the professor chose to start new modules in the middle or end of a lecture. I felt that by simply going through as much of a unit as possible in a lecture made the course seem disorganized and hard to follow.

There is just way too much content, and no obvious common thread of logic to tie it all together. Complicated biological processes are not given enough coverage in class, and students are left to figure out a lot on their own. Enrichment and peer tutoring is critical and the best part of the class.

Strengths: Learned a lot of information in good detail
Weaknesses: Did not get a good big picture, slides and lessons were hard to understand and follow. 

This class could be improved by having slides that were more easy to follow. This could be done by having titles for each slide so you knew what you were looking at when going back through the slides. Also I think it would be worthwhile to go a little slower and cover some more basic cell biology before diving into more complex topics. For example, going through all the organelles and their basic function as a first unit before going into complex experimental methods.

The lectures only superficially covered a ton of information. Simply covering the material with less depth would have made for a better class. This class alone could have covered an entire semester, so cramming it into 4-5 weeks was brutal.

Strengths: There is a focus on problem solving and deep understanding of the material being taught rather than surface-level memorization.
Weaknesses: The course teaches very specific processes without giving a broader picture of cell biology which make the concepts taught difficult to understand. There is also a lot of time spent on experimental methods that doesn't necessarily make sense because it is difficult to understand those methods in a lecture style course in which one never has the chance to use the methods. The class is also quite disorganized and the chronology does not make a lot of sense. It is difficult to understand lectures because key words/phrases/concepts aren't defined before they are used in lecture.

Strengths: challenging
Weaknesses: need more clear explanation, would be good to start more with the basics.

Strengths: 
- There are many support/extra help systems students can use

Weaknesses: 
- I don't like the way Mooseker covers more material at a faster rate if we ask fewer questions; it just leads to people being more confused

Strengths: Engaging
Weaknesses: Focuses too much on minor details and too willing to fail students on psets.

Prof. Mooseker was very hard to understand at times because of the way that he spoke - he spoke very fast and his words would often blend into each other so it was difficult to learn when he was not easy to comprehend as he spoke. The speed of the content in combination with the difficulty of understanding him made it very challenging to keep up with the course - at least one of these needs to change in order for students to actually learn and have useful lecture periods.

This class is overall a strong class - very challenging, but rewarding. It is too fast-paced however, and I would greatly appreciate extending the homework due date to Wednesday instead of Monday to give students more time to seek out help from the peer tutors.

The strength of this course is that exams and psets focuse on applications and interpretations of concepts, not on memorization. The weakness is that the class is taught as though it is focused on memorization. (Mooseker leads long detail-orientated lectures and does not actually teach how to think about the deeper application questions that he expects students to complete on psets and exams.)

Strengths: Awesome course coordinating Professor Lin who runs everything and does a great job. Professor Mooseker is very kind and also does a great job, though his lecture structures can be confusing. Awesome TFs who help a lot and peer tutors who save everyone.

Weaknesses: Lectures are too fast so if you lose focus for 10 seconds it is hard to figure out what happened and not get lost. It took me a long time to figure out the way Prof M structured his lectures which made learning more difficult. The material was hard enough, so having to struggle to figure out how to learn in addition to simply learning was tough.

Content was very interesting and presented in a relatively organized manner. Unfortunately the lectures were hard to understand and I felt as if way too much information was being thrown at us way too quickly in the lectures. The content also didn't feel paced well at times. In the second half of the course  far more material was packed into the last two lectures (those on actin and microtubules) than in any of the other lectures that had been given, making it virtually impossible for me to follow the lectures towards the end of the class. Perhaps if Professor Mooseker talked a little slower and refrained from using technical terms until later in the semester, the lectures would be easier to follow.

The strengths, if you love bio, lucky for you because Mooseker knows A LOT about bio. So much that sometimes its hard to understand what the heck he's talking about. I felt like we went into too much  detail and I learned minuscule details that were to intense for an intro bio course. There was a large jump from 101 to 102 and it was defiantly more challenging.

A strength of this course is how it prepares you for the scientific world: you will learn how to read papers effectively. However, I forgot the material I learned in this class almost immediately. This class could be improved by spending more time on certain topics. However, Mark Mooseker was amazing in his demonstrations, and they truly helped me in this course. This class is hard, but I like the challenge, though >:)

Strengths -- Lots of resources available to help students: enrichment, peer tutors, teaching scholars. 

Weaknesses -- why on earth are the discussion section slides not available?? It makes absolutely no sense.
he could slow down the pace a bit but the whistles did a really good job at doing this
The papers and discussion sections were helpful. The lectures could maybe be made a bit clearer.
Goes super fast, gotta work hard to keep up. A lot to remember. Could be more organized.

Strengths: from what I've hard, very realistic to how biology is presented in a professional context
Weaknesses: there was way too much material expected to be learned on one exam (SIGNIFICANTLY more than any other Yale course I've taken), use of lots of biology jargon without explanation, the expectation that we would know a lot of biological concepts without having been taught them, the organization of lecture slides (the pre-lecture/post-lecture system was confusing and it would have been more helpful to have slides organized simply by unit rather than separately by unit and lecture number)
The lecture material moves very fast, Some of the papers (especially the Listeria one) were very cool.
Too fast paced- not enough time to take notes, and too quick to remember most of the information being taught. TFs and Professor Lin was helpful. Discussion sections helped to solidify knowledge

Strengths IT HAS SAM LIN
Weaknesses it goes too fast and so much material

The course allowed me to understand a lot of the underlying cell processes and why the occur in the way they do. The lecture slides were definitely a very helpful way of organizing the information of the course, and they helped me navigate this vastness of information that I had to memorize. Nonetheless, the distribution and organization of lecture slides in the pre-lecture/post-lecture format was for me somewhat confusing, and created this ambiguity of which slides I should study from, the ones I had taken notes on or the ones that were updated and had answers to the questions posed during lecture. Moreover, I believed that it was not always clear what information should be retained from the papers, and many of the papers seemed disjointed from the topics in the course that we were going over. The course material was extremely specific at times, and deviated from explaining the overarching, fundamental concepts of biology that were of concern to us as students of an introductory biology course. I believe that although the toolkits provide me with information that is essential for me as a future biology major and as a prospective researcher, they are not an effective way of passing down this information to students. I believe that a lab course that would accompany the introductory biology sequence in the same way that a lab course accompanies the introductory chemistry sequence would be a far more effective way for students to be introduced to such toolkit and assay protocol concepts on a more empirical way. Working in a lab during the summer has made me realize that when one is empirically exposed to experimental protocols on a hands-on basis, they are far more able to understand the processes and retain the information that is necessary.
Yes but I would explain that it is not very engaging in class, although the material was interesting.
Absolutely not. Change your major
No. Unless you fully intend on pursuing pre-med, do not take this course.
Unless you have too (i.e. Pre-Med) I would not recommend this course to a student
Only take if you have to. Avoid needless suffering.
Only if your major requires it

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because although a lot of material was covered in a short amount of time, the class was interesting and gave a good introduction into experimental procedures used in cell biology.
Probably not, unless if it's required for a major than they obviously have to take it.
Yes, it's a prerequisite.

I would highly recommend this course to any student who loves science and especially biology, with the warning that if you do not like science and scientific thought, this course can be very difficult.

I don't think I would recommend it to anyone who doesn't have to take it either for their major or for the pre-med track. I only say this because if done right, the course is a lot of work and I don't think it would feel worth it for a non-bio major. Plus anyone without a good amount of prior biology experience would probably find it extremely challenging to keep up with the course.
No. But I guess you have to take it in the bio sequence.
If you like Biology yes. This course was fun and really pushes students to mature in their engagement with biology. If you do not like biology this could be pretty  tough course.

I would recommend this course only if you have to take it or if you want to do research in cell biology. You learn a lot about very specific aspects of cell biology, which is really interesting, but there's also so much about experimental methods that isn't really relevant if that's not what you're going to do with your life.
Yes, if it is required for their major

Most students take this course as a prerequisite and not an elective. I would say that if you're interested in biology, you should take it but if you just wanted to explore the field to see if you're interested in the life sciences, take another class.
No. this class will murder your love of biology.
I do not think I would recommend this course to anyone unless they are on the pre-med track.

(this review is based solely on BIOL 102 with Mooseker). Wow. I don't even know where to begin. This class has been the most challenging, taxing, and distressful course all while being the most enriching and beneficial class I've taken thus far at Yale. 4000 characters are not sufficient enough to describe the roller coaster that was BIOL 102 with Prof. Mooseker. Never have I been so lost yet so engaged with a course before. I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I cannot believe the sheer amount of growth I went through in the 6 weeks of this course. Take this class, and make sure to take it with Moosker. Challenging but SOOO worth it.
No, unless required

A student who is interested in delving deeply into cell biology (lots of actin and myosin included) through reading scientific papers and looking at experimental design would get a lot out of this class! However, time outside of lecture (yes, you have to go to every review session offered by the professor and peer tutors) is necessary to fully internalize the material. Dont take it unless you have the will and the time to fully commit. You dont have to memorize a bunch of terms or anything, but you do have to internalize the concepts, and that can be difficult.
If the course was easier or more doable, I would since I feel like I learned a lot. I would not recommend it as it currently stands.
I would recommend this course even if you don't need the intro Bio sequence. I am not planning on majoring in Biology but this course was very interesting and focused on depth rather than breadth.
Yes, although it was not easy, I thoroughly enjoyed this course.
not unless you have to
Yes, it just requires a lot of individual work.
It is a course that is helpful if you are pre-med or an MCDB major but it is definitely difficult.
I would!  The course material was incredibly interesting.

Yes. I think the course provides a very important foundation for further study in biology or related sciences. Rather than just teaching dry facts, the course provides an introduction to critical analysis of biological systems and the forms of experimentation that can be used to address questions about cellular processes.
I would only recommend if you need to take this sequence because you're pre-med or a bio major
Yes. You have to take this if you're pre-med. The lab techniques will be helpful if you plan on engaging in cell bio research.
YES, it may be a struggle to adapt to Mooseker's teaching style but it is very worth it!
Sure, taught well, very specific detail that is not necessarily important to most people but intellectually stimulating and fun to learn regardless of whether one needs to or not
No.
I would recommend to students who are interested in pursuing biology, but have the mindset that it will not push you in ways that excite you

I would recommend this course to a specific student who knows that they want to take further courses in science. This certainly not a class to take "just for fun" or because they "enjoyed biology in high school". From the start the course dove into more difficult cellular biology topics. Similarly, the way that knowledge is tested requires a level of thinking (and reading) that I, and thus assume most Yale students, have never experienced.
Only if required
Yes but be prepared to struggle on PSETs and information for the exams
Yes. If you are going to work in a biology research any time in college, this course is essential.
maybe with another teacher

Although this course was interesting, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who does not need to take it for their major. It requires a lot of engagement with the material outside of lectures, especially with the p-sets and the requirements for section every week.  For that reason alone, I would not recommend this course to someone who does not need to take it.
I would recommend it.

I would recommend this course only if someone needed it for their major or pre-med requirements.  The material was very interesting, but the class is difficult and I would not recommend taking it just for fun.

I would NOT recommend this course to another student. This course is very dry and the grading for problem sets are very hard. In addition, the midterm and final is very heavy on using the concepts learned in class to apply it to problems. This is not a skill that is as practiced, and there are no previous practice exams to examine from, which makes studying for the course harder.
Yes, it gives a good foundation.

Its very difficult and time-consuming for a first-year, so please dont take this unless its a requirement. Course material is very dense, even without reading the textbook  were talking 100 slides average per lecture. There are more interesting bio classes to take for a science credit.

If you have to take an introductory biology sequence, then you have to take this course. If you want to do it for fun, I really suggest you not -- just for your own sake. I definitely was so proud of myself for all the amazing processes that I had learned about and truly understood after taking this course and it was satisfying to know all the different things our bodies can do on the cellular level. Yet, this was HANDS DOWN the class I put the most effort in so far in my life. I do not think I have studied more for a final than I did for this one just because there was so much content and so much to just understand. Plus, the midterm and final are both very VERY application-based and not memory based so you really have to understand the process down to the receptor (basically the super specific thing).
Only to those who require the intro bio sequence for their majors or premed requirements. To other who look only to explore biology, Id recommend looking elsewhere.
No.
Not with mooseker but what other choice do you have. With a more engaging lecturer- the information is actually really interesting
I would recommend this course to students seeking a challenge. Although the material in incredibly interesting, it is not taught in a very accessible manner.

I would recommend this course to others who may not have gotten a great foundation in biology because you really understand the fundamentals to different parts of cell biology all within a half semester course.
Yes and no. It was hard because of how much was material was covered but it is somewhat okay if you continually ask for help.
Nah. Even if you have to take BIOL 102 as a prerequisite, make sure you do not have professor Mooseker as a teacher.
No because the material is not interesting, there is a decent amount of work, and it is challenging.
Would only recommend if it is a requirement for a major or pre-med.
Not really but most people have to take it anyway
only if you need it for a prerequisite.

Absolutely not.  We had to have review sessions on Saturday AND Sunday that just went over all the material Mooseker "taught" in class.  And everyone would go because lectures were taught so poorly.  Professor Lin was great though and really understood that Mooseker's lectures were not directed to our studies but his own research interests.
No, not unless they need to take this course.

Yes; cell bio is interesting even if there's a lot of material covered, just keep going to review sessions and ask TAs lots of questions to fill in the gaps in material not covered in lecture due to time constraints

Prof. Mooseker is an expert in his field, but he simply does not explain things well; he is one of those professors who struggles to connect with students who have a little to no experience in biology. So that makes lecture often confusing and difficult to follow. Even though he is very encouraging of asking questions during lecture, it is often hard to even formulate a question with the overload of new information we get every class. However, if you read the book, go to section, and spend time with the psets, you'll learn a lot. Just don't expect to get too much out of lecture. The tests are also tough and require a lot of studying, but they're fair.

I would not recommend it for students who want a low workload biology/science credit course. It is very challenging and requires a lot of time on your part to reach the level that Professor Mooseker expected from us.
This class is good for covering the basic concepts of cell bio.

Yes, because Professor Mooseker is so cool and fascinating as a person! I really enjoyed delving into the complexities of cell bio and learning about motor proteins and things that have amazed me for so long.
Its very difficult for an intro level course so probably not
No unless it is required

Chances are, students looking at this class have to take it as a prereq for their major and will have little choice about it. That being said, if you don't need this class, don't take it. There are plenty of other fun science classes that can be taken instead (even guts, if that's what you're looking for). This class, as is, is only worth suffering through if you have no other option, and it won't be enjoyable.
Yes, you will learn a lot, but be prepared to do a lot of reviewing lecture slides outside of class.
Yes, this is a must for students who are interested in biology or just want to know who life works.
Not really. This class is kinda dull and quite difficult

no, unless they need to take the sequence for their major. I really don't think that the course is great, and I can't even imagine how much worse it would be for students with zero bio background. the teacher needs to slow down and maybe pick fewer concepts to go in depth, because theres no point to brushing over lots of stuff and understanding none of it.
Cell bio is very difficult with lots of information to be covered. However, once you understand the content, it is very interesting.
Yes, for the premed requirement.

Absolutely, many need it for pre med or other major requirements. Professor Mooseker is difficult to follow at times, but hes truly invested in the class and there to help. You do actually leave the class with an awareness of lab techniques that serve you well in your individual research as well. Id say its worthwhile to take it.
Yes, if you are really interested in cellular function.
I would only if you really like biology or want to major in it.
If they have to for requirements, then yes.
Yes but remain upbeat and on your feet
Yes it is good but you need to think
Yes  only if this is required. Otherwise, this is so much work and a lot of the information you probably wont need.
I would not unless they were required to take the class.

Yes, if you are interested in majoring in cell bio at Yale (even just a little), absolutely take this course; it is a great way to gauge your interest in the field and determine whether or not you are ready for the upper level cell bio courses offered at Yale, because this course is definitely reflective of upper level biology courses.
I would recommend this course if they have taken ap biology.

I would recommend this to premeds or students interested in research. Although the material taught is very interesting, there is a monstrous amount of it. It is also sometimes difficult to tell what is important to know and what is extraneous. Despite this, it was a very thought-provoking way to teach biology, which is often just memorization. It also introduces students to the experimental methods important to cell bio research, which is very  valuable.
No. It was really difficult to understand the material from lecture.
No
If you are really interested in biology, then yes. Otherwise, this is not a gut class.
Yes if its required.
Yes
The course was challenging but I feel like I have learned a lot and am proud of my effort. I would recommend this course to students who know they are interested in biology.

This course is pretty much only one to be taken if it's required for your major or premed. It wasn't super interesting - while the content should've been fascinating, the way Professor Mooseker teaches takes much of the fun out of it, and the sheer amount of content we are supposed to absorb makes taking this class just a rush to cram as much information as possible instead of actually understanding it.

This course is supposed to be an introductory biology course, but it did not feel that way at all. It felt very difficult and convoluted. If you are not very interested in bio or taking the class as a requirement I would not recommend taking it.
I wouldn't recommend the class to anyone that didn't have to take it for their major.
I would only take this course if it is a requirement. It is not a good introduction to biology/cell biology.
I would so that they can learn basic biology.
I would only recommend this course if they have to take it. The course is not generally interesting or engaging in itself.
Not really unless necessary for the major or premed. This class made it incredibly difficult for me to succeed, and I felt terrible about myself for weeks. Not worth the stress.
I would not recommend taking this course with Prof. Mooseker since you can take the same course with other professors that are much easier to understand.
I would recommend this course to another student if they were very interested in biology and had the time to accommodate the workload and difficulty.
I would recommend this course to another student. The class is time consuming and difficult, but very interesting, and teaches you how to think like a scientist, not just like a science student.

Yes. Considering you gotta take this if you're at all interested in bio, it doesn't matter. But, I will say it's not as bad as everyone say. Find someone to study with, get to know your TF and Professor Lin, and go to all the review sessions.

If you are vaguely interested in life sciences then I think you should definitely take this course to see if one of the biology majors is right for you. The content of 102 is far more interesting than 101 and quite interesting for me personally. Although Prof. Moosekers lectures are incredibly hard to follow, the textbook and slides are generally quite clear, so it is more than possible to get through the course if one cannot retain much from lecture.
Most people don't take bio102 for fun, it's usually a requirement. Good luck if you have Mooseker because it will be much harder, but you will also learn a lot more.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in an introduction to cell biology: it is quite informative, and not too much of a weed-out class like other courses in the bio and STEM departments. This class, although less enjoyable than BIOL 101, is still fun, especially when trying to read papers with friends (lots of questions will be asked on what the figure even depicts). However, be warned, LOTS of pre-meds take this class, so there will be lots of people trying their best to get a 100% on all the tests (hint: grades don't matter y'all).

Definitely. It can be pretty challenging at times (most of the times), but I have emerged on the other side, slightly war torn, but mostly proud of how I have become a better Biology student and Yale student.
yes, learned a lot!
Yes, this class was a good introduction to cell biology.
Yep, learned so much in just half a semester, and it was pretty interesting!

No, I would not recommend this course to another student unless they needed to fulfill pre-med requirements. Even then, I might recommend they take it in the fall. I felt that the sheer amount of information we were expected to memorize in this course made it a very stressful experience and I would definitely caution non-pre-med students to take satisfy their science requirement through other courses.
There's a lot of cool material in this course, but if you don't have a strong biology background and it's not required, it's probably more stress than it's worth.
Yes, but only if they need it for their intended major.
It's ok

This was course was definitely interesting and exciting and it covered a great number of topics in cell biology. For most people this course is going to be a prerequisite that they have to cover in order to either study any of the biology majors at Yale, or move into medical school. Although this course is extremely interesting, it covers a lot of information and it can be fairly intimidating for people that have very little background in biology. Therefore, I would suggest that one takes this course if they are interested in biology as a subject but are willing to put a lot of work into it.
